author: The Tico Times
title: PHOTOS: A look back at how Guatemalan citizens demanded justice – and won
text:
Each Saturday for five straight months, Guatemalans gathered in the capital’s Plaza de la Constitución to demand the resignation of then-President Otto Pérez Molina, accused of being the mastermind behind a massive customs fraud mafia known as “La Línea,” as reported by the daily Prensa Libre and other media around the world.
Citizens of all stripes across Guatemala joined in the demonstrations in their own cities and villages, linked by social media and hashtags like #YoNoTengoPresidente (“I don’t have a president”). And in dramatic fashion, in the span of a few short days this week, the Guatemalan Congress voted to strip Pérez Molina of his immunity from prosecution in the ongoing corruption probe. Pérez Molina resigned just before midnight on Wednesday, and Congress accepted his resignation on Thursday , swearing in 79-year-old Alejandro Maldonado as the country’s new president.
Not long after, also on Thursday, a judge ordered Pérez Molina held in provisional prison pending the continuance of a criminal hearing on whether he will formally face a corruption trial. That hearing is scheduled to continue on Tuesday, and Pérez Molina – who has gone from Guatemala City’s Presidential Palace to the Matamoros military prison – will spend Sunday’s general elections behind bars, a hard-fought victory for many of the country’s advocates for justice.
Here’s a look back in photos of that dramatic, tenacious and peaceful protest movement that since April has been inspiring the world.
Demonstrators hold signs during a protest against Guatemala’s former President Otto Pérez Molina and former Vice President Roxana Baldetti in Guatemala City, on April 25, 2015.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Constitution Square, Guatemala City, May 16, 2015. Former Vice President Roxana Baldetti resigned on May 8.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
In front of the justice tribunals in Guatemala City, on May 30, 2015.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Constitution Square, Guatemala City on June 20, 2015. Pressure mounted for then-President Otto Pérez Molina to resign. He would do just that a little over two months later.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Guatemala City, July 4, 2015.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Guatemala’s historical center, Aug. 15, 2015. The Guatemalan Congress voted against stripping Otto Pérez Molina of his presidential immunity from prosecution. In a second vote less than a month later, lawmakers voted again. This time, Pérez Molina lost.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Guatemala City, Aug. 23, 2015. Citizens young and old bang their drums demanding Otto Pérez Molina resign. The defiant president refused. The sign on the drum says “Otto Pérez, get out. Guatemala doesn’t want you.”
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Indigenous Guatemalans march and block a street in Guatemala City on Aug. 27, 2015. That week, Pérez Molina suffered a double setback as the country’s top prosecutor called for his resignation and his ex-vice president was sent to jail.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Otto Pérez Molina’s lawyer, César Calderón, right, delivers a report on the corruption scandal to a congressional investigative committee.
Orlando Sierra/AFP
Strong images of Stalin, Hitler and Pérez Molina in Guatemala City on Aug. 29, 2015 as a congressional committee recommends Otto Pérez Molina be stripped of his immunity.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
“We want #105. Guate has dignity.” They got 105, and then some, as 132 lawmakers voted to strip Pérez Molina of his immunity, in Guatemala City, Sept. 1, 2015.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Sept. 3, 2015 is a date that will go down in Guatemalan history. It is the date that the Guatemalan people learned that Otto Pérez Molina, who came to power in 2012 promising to crack down on crime, resigned, just before midnight the previous day.
Rodrigo Arangua/AFP
Protests were mostly peaceful and often colorful and energetic. This one took place in front of the Supreme Elections Tribunal in Guatemala City, on Sept. 3, 2015.
Rodrigo Arangua/AFP
Otto Pérez Molina speaks with journalists at the end of a hearing at the Supreme Court in Guatemala City, on Sept. 3, 2015. That day, Judge Miguel Ángel Gálvez ordered his provisional detention.
Johan Ordóñez/AFP
Guess who’s riding in this car? Otto Pérez Molina arrives at the Matamoros military barracks in Guatemala City, on Sept. 3, 2015, his new home, at least until Tuesday.
Orlando Estrada/AFP
Guatemalan President Alejandro Maldonado Aguirre receives military honors during a ceremony at the Defense Ministry in Guatemala City, on Sept. 4, 2015. That day, Guatemala’s Congress swore in Maldonado as head of state.
Rodrigo Arangua/AFP
